title: Labour denies leaked poll is linked to search for Corbyn's successor | Politics | The Guardian
text:
Labour Labour denies leaked poll is linked to search for Corbyn's successor 
The party rebuts Sunday Times story and insists focus group research testing voters’ opinion on two frontbenchers has nothing to do leadership challenge The focus group found Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn to be ‘boring’ and looking ‘like a scruffy school kid’. Photograph: Peter Byrne/PA View more sharing options Sunday 12 February 2017 10.57 GMT Last modified on Sunday 12 February 2017 10.59 GMT 
Labour has denied that a poll conducted in the north of England to test the appeal of key frontbenchers was about finding Jeremy Corbyn ’s successor. 
The Sunday Times obtained a leaked copy of internal party polling that used a focus group testing voters’ reactions to shadow business secretary Rebecca Long-Bailey and shadow education secretary Angela Rayner . Labour in crisis: Can the party reconnect with its heartland? Read more 
The pair are both regarded as rising stars of the 2015 intake of MPs from the left of the party, and Long-Bailey was promoted in last week’s reshuffle , after four shadow ministers resigned over Corbyn’s Brexit stance. 
According to the Sunday Times, the focus group responses to Rayner were “overwhelmingly negative”. 
The MP for Ashton-under-Lyne was judged by the group to be “not likeable”, a “bit charity shop-looking” and “weird”, with one participant suggesting voters would not take her seriously, the newspaper reported. 
Long-Bailey, a former lawyer and the MP for Salford and Eccles, was viewed more favourably with the group describing her as “passionate”, “genuine”, “sincere” and “very smart”, although some saw her as “aggressive” and “rough”. 
A Labour source insisted the focus group had nothing to do with the future of the leadership. 
“In common with all political parties, Labour conducts polling to get a clearer picture of views in different parts of the country,” they told the Guardian. Clive Lewis dismisses talk he could challenge Corbyn for leadership Read more 
“Polling of northern voters was about how best to get Labour’s message across in the north and has nothing at all to do with ‘succession planning’.” 
The source added that similar exercises will be carried out in other parts of the country. 
Corbyn’s team had already been forced to deny rumours last week that the 67-year-old leader had named a date for his departure. 
Voters also appear to have been sceptical about Corbyn’s appeal in the focus group. 
The group, organised by Labour’s pollster BMG Research, found Corbyn to be “boring”, said he appeared “fed up” and “looks like a scruffy school kid”. 
The Labour source refused to comment on suggestions the polling also pointed to Labour being reduced to 198 seats to the Tories’ 361 if a general election were held in the coming months.
